Gaping holes on pavement at Anna Nagar p.description: MADURAI: Walking on the middle of the road is no doubt suicidal, but in Anna Nagar, walking along the pavement meant for pedestrians can be even more dangerous. Chances are that your leg will get caught in a deep gaping hole on the one-kilometre stretch. The stretch of the 80 feet road on Anna Nagar main road, from Ambiga theatre to Golcha complex, has a pavement bordering the road continuously except at places where the streets intercept. The elevated pavement has been laid over a drainage. Morning walkers are seen walking along this stretch, but they prefer to walk on the road as the pavement is not safe. ``Most of the holes in the pavement are visible only during daytime, and anyone falling in could have a serious accident, as there is no foothold below the pavement,’’ said K Thiagarajan of Anna Nagar. This long running pavement is at the entrance of many shops that have started dotting the area, many of them large shops, banks, bank ATMs, eateries, fruits stalls, grocery shops and medical shops. Most of these shops have used boards to close the holes in front of their shops, which makes them more dangerous. ``We did make some representations about two years ago, but nothing was done,’’ said Kumar, a shopkeeper. In places like the bus stop at Suguna store, the holes are big and can result in a person falling into it if the stone kept temporarily gets damaged or breaks, say these shopkeepers. Shanthi, who takes a bus regularly from the Suguna store bus stop, says she does not remember the last time she walked on the pavement. ``Sometimes when I see the bus and must run for it, chances are that I would fall into these holes. So I prefer to run on the middle of the road and stop it,’’ she said. The area is one that has become famous for window shopping, but the shoppers prefer to walk on the road and see the shops rather than on the platform due to its bad condition. ``It would benefit the shops if the people had closer access to the showcases, but the pavement situation makes it impossible,’’ said Krishna, a shopkeeper. City Engineer S Arasu said that the pavements would be surveyed and repaired after preparing an estimate at the earliest. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Probe team to visit PHC where woman died.description: MADURAI: A medical team comprising officials from the Tirunelveli district health department as well as other experts has been formed to conduct further inquiry into the death of a 23-year-old woman after giving birth to a stillborn baby earlier this month at a primary health centre (PHC) in Thirukkurunkudi. The delivery was performed by a PHC employee in the absence of a doctor. The team – which includes the deputy director of health services (DDHS), deputy director of family welfare and joint director of health services from the district — apart from the dean and team of obstetricians from Tirunelveli medical college – would be conducting an inspection at the hospital on Monday. The DDHS of Tirunelveli, Dr S Senthil Kumar, had already submitted a report earlier but according to the officials, the team has been formed to have a more comprehensive probe into the issue. “We will be conducting an inspection and submitting the report to the director of public health and preventive medicine (K Kolandaswamy) and mission director of National Health Mission (Dr Darez Ahamed),” DDHS Dr Senthil Kumar said. Officials from the comprehensive emergency obstetrics and newborn care (CeMONC) would also be part of the inspection. The state human rights commission had also taken suo motu congizance of the deaths and sought a report from the state health department regarding the incident. It may be recalled that based on the initial inspection, officials had said that there was no doctor for the afternoon duty at the PHC and the auxiliary nurse midwife (ANM) who was present there performed the delivery. The reason for the death of the mother was said to be bleeding during delivery while the baby was stillborn following complications from the umbilical cord getting wrapped around its neck. SP told to file status of cheating case.description: Madurai: The superintendent of police (SP) Trichy has been directed to file a status report on July 9 in a case where a person was arrested for cheating several women of their money on the pretext of marrying them. The direction was given by a division bench of justice M Sathyanarayanan and justice B Pugalendhi of the Madurai bench of the Madras high court on Monday. In the petition, an advocate, T Jayanthi Rani who is the managing trustee of an NGO Parents Trust based at Trichy, stated that in March this year, their trust received a serious complaint from a widowed woman who was cheated by a person though a matrimonial website. She said that the person went with different names such as Ajay, Vidhu, Vidyut, Vijayakumar, Chakravarthy and posed himself as a medical practitioner in a foreign country and got acquainted with the victim women through the matrimonial website. She noted that Ajay had received a huge sum of money from the victim on the pretext of marrying her. Later, the woman came to know that the person had cheated several other women through matrimonial websites. TNN Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
